Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Causes and Effects of Shelf-Edge Internal Tide Variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
Internal tide generation and propagation near continental slopes will be studied using a four-dimensional numerical simulation and diagnosis approach. The purpose is to explain observed variability in internal tides and the nonlinear waves they spawn. The study will concentrate on long wavelength linear internal waves (internal tides) generated from sub-critical tidal flow (current speed less than wave speed), ubiquitous around the world. Three internal tide effects will be examined: variable generation, heterogeneous propagation, and conversion to nonlinear waveform. A set of simulations will be performed with the MIT Multidisciplinary Simulation, Estimation, and Assimilation System (MSEAS), mostly with the hydrostatic primitive equation model already tuned at mesoscales via comparison with data. Modeled configurations will range from idealized bathymetric, stratification, and flow conditions to realistic conditions obtained via data-driven modeling. Inter-comparisons of the collected results will divulge the physics of variable four-dimensional internal tide generation and propagation, with the intent of describing how the process occurs in the real ocean. The new MSEAS non-hydrostatic model will then be used to study nonlinear conversion processes. Applicability of the results to the real ocean will be verified via comparison to remote sensing and in situ data from a one-month long experiment.

This work will lead to better understanding and accurate modeling of interactions of mesoscale and sub-mesoscale features, surface and internal tides, origins of nonlinear internal waves, and strong variability of these processes. Hydrostatic and non-hydrostatic primitive equation models using different numerical schemes will be evaluated for internal tide predictions. Internal tides and nonlinear internal waves, and their interactions with larger scales, impact a wide range of natural and man-made activities. These include life cycles and distributions of oxygen, nutrients, plankton, fish, and other predators, naval operations and surveillance, underwater acoustics, and patterns of diapycnal mixing and water mass development in the summer season of strong stratification. In addition, these waves are a major source of shear, strong bottom currents, and cycling of water between sunlight and darkness. They are energy sources for mixing processes which are important to benthic habitat, plankton and fish life cycles, and distributions of nutrients and contaminants. All results, including model outputs, will be disseminated to ocean researchers and communities. A coastal oceanography student will be educated and a post-doctoral fellow further instructed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored the properties of propagating internal tidal waves, which are internal gravity waves at tidal frequencies that are caused by the phenomena of currents of surface tidal waves in density-layered water being deflected upward by sloping seabeds, a process that converts kinetic energy (motion) into potential energy that then drives the new form of motion, the internal tides. The resulting internal tidal waves often transform to packets of strong nonlinear internal waves spaced at intervals related to tidal periodicity, but these waves are very irregular compared to the tides that provide the original forcing. These waves often form a large fraction of the kinetic energy in continental shelf waters, and their motions impact many of the physical and biogeochemical features of those environments. Internal tides are characterized by differences in the speed and direction of water motion with height in the water, whereas regular surface tide motions are essentially uniform with height.

First steps in understanding the complexity of the full internal-tide/nonlinear wave system, to aid understanding how these motions of the water affect the chemistry (nutrients and other materials of interest) and the life forms in these places, are to understand the generation, propagation and dissipation of the internal tides. Here, the propagation is the main research target. Tools used to study the wave propagation are taken from optics, namely ray tracing, from waveguide studies, namely modal wave property computations, and from so-called coupled mode propagation studies for waveguides. New methods for calculating the modal wave properties were developed; an expansion of an existing theory, and a new numerical solution method. The modal waves have the interesting quality of having different wavelengths in different directions because of the action of currents. Some work has been done in the past on waves of this type, but the work we have found was not complete, and we have developed some new methods to computationally anaylze the behavior of these waves. The coupled mode work led to a publication showings some details of waves in the area of the Gulfs Stream that explain some observations.

The new methods show that local current and water density conditions will cause waves to refract (thus changing direction) more than they would be predicted to using the older less complete methods. Theory has underpredicted this complexity of propagation; the new theories show that propagation is more complex than earlier thought. However, propagation complexity alone does not explain some observations, complexity in the generation must also play a role. One interesting aspect of the modal waves of variable wavelength is that they can be trapped by currents,  a behavior that we are analyzing in follow-up work.

Experience was gained by an early career scientist who first worked on the project as a postdoctoral associate, then as an early career professor. This was an educational impact.
